thread.section_title: Palm Beach County High School Sports - Sun Sentinel
thread.title: Monarch, Calvary Christian shine at Spanish River Invite
thread.title_full: Monarch, Calvary Christian shine at Spanish River Invite - Sun Sentinel

author: John Santagata
title: Monarch, Calvary Christian shine at Spanish River Invite
text:
It was all part of the plan.
Monarch sophomore Nicole McConnell was aiming for a personal best at the 33 r d annual Spanish River Invitational on Saturday morning.
She got it ... and then some.
McConnell finished the 5K race at South County Regional Park in a career-best 19 minutes, 55.08 seconds, capturing the girls 4A title in front of more than 70 teams, 2,000 athletes and hundreds of spectators.
"I kinda thought I would beat it," said McConnell, referencing her previous best time (20:51) that she set at last year's regional meet. "The weather was right and I love this course."
Spanish River Invitational Results Spanish River Invitational
Boys team scores (3A)
Okeechobee 51, Doral Academy Charter 63, Dwyer 63, Sebastian River 66, Jensen Beach 106, West Boca 185
Individual results
1. Rosado (DA) 17:43.01; 2. Van Marter (D) 18:17.65; 3. Sils (O) 18:17.65; 4. Seibenick (JB) 18:29.60; 5. Patterson (O) 18:33.58;...
Spanish River Invitational
Boys team scores (3A)
Okeechobee 51, Doral Academy Charter 63, Dwyer 63, Sebastian River 66, Jensen Beach 106, West Boca 185
Individual results
1. Rosado (DA) 17:43.01; 2. Van Marter (D) 18:17.65; 3. Sils (O) 18:17.65; 4. Seibenick (JB) 18:29.60; 5. Patterson (O) 18:33.58;...
Read the story She needed it.
Coral Reef High's Rachel Osman (20:41.77) and Park Vista's Barbara Prol (20:41.90) were right behind her.
"[McConnell's] a front-runner," Monarch coach Jamil Wilcox said. "That's what she's used to. She's not used to the tapering and all that. She's just used to being in front and winning."
The Pine School sophomore Courtney Barber captured the 1A title in 21:34.20, edging out Riviera Prep's Nicole Katzarkov (21:43.59) and Kings Academy's Mia Rodriguez (21:42.82).
Rival eighth-graders Natalie Varela, of Gulliver Prep, and Rahyah Andressohn didn't disappoint, each earning individual titles. Varela ran away from the 2A field in 18:53.28, the only girl to run a sub-19 minute race.
Andressohn claimed the 3A title in 19:30.76.
Bolstered by four top-15 finishes, the North Broward Prep girls team won the overall 2A team title with 73 points. Saint Andrew's finished fifth, followed by Calvary Christian, Gulliver Academy and Oxbridge Academy.
King's Academy captured the 1A girls team title, and Barber's win helped Pine School finish third.
"I had a feeling we would win," North Broward coach Chelsea Gilbert said. "We actually were going to just use this meet as a workout because we just ran [Thursday], but we found out we were the No. 1 seed, so the girls came out with a little bit more, and we ended up winning."
Douglas finished third in 4A to top Broward County , as Coral Springs placed eighth and Cooper City ninth.
Park Vista finished fourth to lead Palm Beach teams, while Boca Raton placed sixth and meet host Spanish River finished 10 t h .
Dwyer's girls team finished third in 3A, but it was the Panthers' boys team that stole the spotlight.
The Panthers' boys team had three top-10 finishes, leading to a second place finish for Dwyer, which earned 63 points.
"I was shooting for top 5," Panthers boys coach Glenn Roebach said. "To be shorthanded and to come out and perform the way they did speaks a lot about their will to succeed."
Carlin Berryhill's desire to prosper was evident.
The Coral Reef senior dominated on his favorite course, finishing in 16:16.80, which was 15 seconds faster than his next closest competitor, to easily win the 4A individual title.
John I. Leonard's Ilio Sanchez sought to finish closer to Berryhill, but a bad start led to a fifth place finish.
"I got closed in and bumped a few times when we got into the shoot," said Sanchez, referring to the point on the course where the pack funnels into a single line. "I got out of my rhythm and then I had to push at a harder pace to try and catch back up."
The Spanish River boys team finished fourth in 4A, Leonard fifth, Park Vista eighth and Palm Beach Central rounded out the top 10.
Calvary Christian dominated the field to win the 2A team title with 32 points. Danny Ferro won the race in 16:57.81 to pace the team, while Joel Lacy (third), David Hernandez (fourth), Brett Herbert (11 t h ) and Geoffrey Still (13 t h ) also placed.
"That was expected," Calvary coach Scott Sherrod. "I knew if we ran our race, we would win it."
It was all part of the plan.
